description: Probably from  Joe Zilch, a placeholder name (compare John Doe) used by Nunnally Johnson in his column in the Brooklyn Daily Eagle from 1923; in turn from Joe Zilch, an unseen character referenced in comedian Frank Tinney's stage routine. Compare the rare German surname Zilch.

entries.meaning: (countable, informal, archaic) A nobody: a person who is worthless in importance or character.

examples: Her search for decent home-made winter clothes came up with zilch, so she had to get imported stuff.

verbs.description: zilch (third-person singular simple present zilches, present participle zilching, simple past and past participle zilched)

entries.meaning: (informal, US sports) To cause to score nothing, to thoroughly defeat.
examples: We zilched them on that rubber.
